questions.prompt: What was Jesus correcting when Nicodemus assumed the kingdom could be entered through heritage and religious status?
choices: The need for more miracles
The idea that morality alone earns entrance
The belief that birth into Israel guarantees kingdom life
The value of Scripture study

questions.prompt: In John 3, why does Jesus use “birth” language instead of “try harder” language?
choices: Because humans can gradually train the flesh into holiness
Because spiritual life is received by God’s action, not self-produced
Because knowledge of doctrine automatically creates new life
Because religion is mainly about improving behavior

questions.prompt: “Born of water and of the Spirit” most directly points to what theme in the lesson?
choices: A required ritual that causes regeneration
Cleansing and inward renewal promised by God, accomplished by the Spirit
The importance of temple washings for salvation
The need to feel spiritual emotions before believing

questions.prompt: According to the lesson, what can the “flesh” produce at best?
choices: True spiritual life that pleases God
A new heart that loves Christ
More flesh — behavior polishing without inward rebirth
Perfect holiness through discipline

questions.prompt: Which statement best matches the “new creature” emphasis tied to 2 Corinthians 5:17?
choices: A believer becomes instantly flawless
A believer receives a new center of gravity: new desire and direction under a new Master
A believer earns a fresh start through consistent effort
A believer’s past no longer matters, so repentance is unnecessary

questions.prompt: Acts 3:19 presents repentance and conversion leading to what two outcomes?
choices: Spiritual gifts and prosperity
Sins blotted out and times of refreshing from the Lord’s presence
Public respect and social peace
A life with fewer temptations

questions.prompt: In the lesson, repentance is best described as:
choices: A one-time doorway you outgrow
A shame-based punishment that keeps you fearful
An ongoing posture—turning from sin and toward God as the Spirit works
A private feeling you keep to yourself

questions.prompt: Psalm 51 shows repentance as primarily concerned with:
choices: Avoiding consequences and protecting reputation
Negotiating with God to reduce punishment
Restored fellowship with God and inner cleansing
Proving to others you changed

questions.prompt: Which pairing reflects the lesson’s warning about the enemy twisting repentance?
choices: Fear: “Confess so people approve you” / Pride: “Work harder to be saved”
Fear: “If I confess, God will reject me” / Pride: “I don’t need to confess; I’m fine”
Fear: “Never feel conviction” / Pride: “Never seek forgiveness”
Fear: “God ignores sin” / Pride: “God rewards sin”

questions.prompt: What does Psalm 51 call “the sacrifices of God”?
choices: Burnt offerings done regularly
A broken spirit and a broken, contrite heart God will not despise
Public fasting and visible sorrow
Paying back what you stole before forgiveness

questions.prompt: In 1 John 5:11–13, assurance is grounded primarily in:
choices: How strong your feelings are during worship
God’s testimony (“record”) about His Son and eternal life
Never struggling with sin again
Your ability to explain theology perfectly

questions.prompt: According to the lesson, “This is the record” functions like:
choices: A motivational slogan
A private opinion you adopt
A courtroom-like witness statement—God’s sworn testimony
A church tradition passed down

questions.prompt: What is the sharp line 1 John draws to clarify who has life?
choices: Those who behave well have life
Those who have the Son have life; those who do not have the Son do not have life
Those with religious knowledge have life
Those with spiritual experiences have life

questions.prompt: In John 10, the believer’s security is pictured as resting in:
choices: The sheep’s strength and consistency
The Shepherd’s giving of life and keeping power—no one can pluck them out
The temple system and offerings
The community’s approval

questions.prompt: Which statement best reflects the lesson’s view of true assurance?
choices: Assurance makes you coast because you’re safe
Assurance prepares you to tell your testimony with gratitude, not fear
Assurance means you never doubt again
Assurance is earned by obedience

questions.prompt: In Ephesians 2, Paul starts the story of salvation with:
choices: What you promised God
What God did—He “quickened” (made alive) the dead
What the church taught you
What your family modeled

questions.prompt: The lesson describes grace as:
choices: God meeting you halfway if you prove sincerity
God coming all the way to the dead and bound, giving life where there was none
God overlooking sin without dealing with justice
God rewarding moral improvement

questions.prompt: “Not of works, lest any man should boast” is used to show:
choices: Works are always sinful
Works can purchase grace if done consistently
God saves in a way that shuts down pride and self-congratulation
Only certain works count

questions.prompt: According to the lesson, good works are:
choices: The root of salvation
Optional once you believe
The fruit of being God’s workmanship—created in Christ to walk in them
Proof you were never dead in sin

questions.prompt: The “bedrock” beneath new birth, repentance, and assurance is:
choices: Human determination
Religious ceremony
Grace—God’s initiative in salvation
Social belonging

questions.prompt: Hebrews 11 presents faith as “substance” and “evidence.” In the lesson, that means faith:
choices: Is blind guessing with no reason
Makes God’s promised realities weighty and present, even when unseen
Depends mainly on emotional intensity
Replaces obedience with optimism

questions.prompt: In the lesson’s framing, Hebrews 11 is primarily:
choices: A detached inspirational chapter for posters
Battlefield encouragement to endure when obedience is costly
A proof that suffering means God is absent
A list of heroes to entertain us

questions.prompt: “Without faith it is impossible to please him” is explained as:
choices: God only rewards perfect people
Faith being the fitting posture toward the living God who has spoken
Faith being optional if you do enough works
Faith being the same as religious tradition

questions.prompt: According to Hebrews 11:6, faith includes believing:
choices: God exists and can be manipulated
God is, and He rewards those who diligently seek Him
God only helps those who help themselves
God ignores unbelief if you’re sincere

questions.prompt: Galatians 2:20 is used to show that faith is not only how you start with Christ, but how you:
choices: Achieve self-improvement
Live daily—“Christ liveth in me” shaping identity and obedience
Avoid hardship
Replace repentance with confidence

questions.prompt: In Matthew 5:6, Jesus blesses those who hunger and thirst after:
choices: Comfort and success
Righteousness—what aligns with God’s will and character
Knowledge and reputation
Religious appearances

questions.prompt: The lesson stresses hunger is not:
choices: A sign of life
Something you can feel during dryness
Something you must manufacture through hype
An appetite God intends to satisfy

questions.prompt: The promise “they shall be filled” is explained as:
choices: A reward for disciplined personalities
God Himself filling the hunger He creates; satisfaction found where God says it is
Proof that Christians never struggle
Guaranteed emotional highs

questions.prompt: Psalm 42’s deer imagery (“panteth”) is used to picture:
choices: A calm, casual interest in God
A soul gasping with real need for the living God
A believer who has no questions
A person who has outgrown worship

questions.prompt: A key move in Psalm 42 is the believer learning to:
choices: Ignore emotions completely
Talk to his soul and command hope in God instead of surrendering to despair
Prove faith by never feeling down
Stop gathering with God’s people
